dame_bs packageïƒ

Submodulesïƒ

dame_bs.binary_search moduleïƒ

dame_bs.binary_search.attempting_insertion_using_binary_search(alpha, delta, n, m, user_samples)[source]ïƒ

Perform the localization phase of DAME using a private binary search.

This procedure partitions the interval [-1, 1] into three segments at each iteration, uses randomized response to privately count how many user sample-means fall into the left and right thirds, and discards the less-likely segment. It repeats until all groups are exhausted, returning the remaining interval.

Parameters:ïƒ

alphafloat

Differential privacy parameter for the binary (randomized response) queries.

deltafloat

Failure probability tolerated in the localization phase.

nint

Number of users allocated to localization (should be n/2 of the total).

mint

Number of samples per user.

user_sampleslist of array-like

A list of length n, each entry an array-like of m real-valued samples for one user.

Returns:ïƒ

List :

[L,R] = The estimated interval that might contain true mean where L is the lower and R is the upper bound.

dame_bs.dame_bs moduleïƒ

dame_bs.dame_bs.dame_with_binary_search(n, alpha, m, user_samples, delta=0.1)[source]ïƒ

Implements DAME algorithm with Binary search (localization phase) and Estimation Phase.

Parameters:

  • n â€“ number of users (integer, even)

  • alpha â€“ privacy parameter

  • m â€“ number of samples per user

  • user_samples â€“ list or array of shape (n, m)

Returns:

estimated mean

Return type:

bar_theta

dame_bs.utils moduleïƒ

dame_bs.utils.plot_errorbars_and_upper_bounds(x_values, mean_errors, std_errors, upper_bounds, xlabel, ylabel, title)[source]ïƒ

Plots error bars and theoretical upper bounds on a single graph.

This function is typically used to visualize the mean squared errors alongside their corresponding theoretical upper bounds for different values (e.g., alpha or n or delta).

Parameters:

  • x_values (list or array-like) â€“ X-axis values (e.g., alpha values or user counts).

  • mean_errors (list or array-like) â€“ Mean squared error values corresponding to alphas.

  • std_errors (list or array-like) â€“ Standard deviation of the errors for each value in alphas.

  • upper_bounds (list or array-like) â€“ Theoretical upper bounds to be plotted as a dashed line.

  • xlabel (str) â€“ Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str) â€“ Label for the y-axis.

  • title (str) â€“ Title of the plot.

Returns:

None. Displays the plot using matplotlib.pyplot.

dame_bs.utils.run_dame_experiment(n, alpha, m, true_mean, trials=50, distribution='normal', delta=0.1)[source]ïƒ

Runs the DAME-BS algorithm multiple times to empirically evaluate its estimation error under different data distributions and privacy settings.

This function simulates a scenario with n users, each having m samples generated from a specified distribution centered around a known true_mean.

Parameters:

  • n (int) â€“ Total number of users participating in the experiment.

  • alpha (float) â€“ Differential privacy parameter. Higher values allow more accurate estimation with weaker privacy guarantees.

  • m (int) â€“ Number of samples collected per user.

  • true_mean (float) â€“ The actual mean of the underlying data distribution. Used to compute estimation error.

  • trials (int, optional) â€“ Number of times the experiment is repeated (default is 50).

  • distribution (str, optional) â€“

    Type of distribution to sample user data from. Supported values:

    • â€normalâ€ : Samples from N(true_mean, 0.5^2)

    • â€uniformâ€ : Samples from U(true_mean - 1, true_mean + 1)

    • â€poissonâ€ : Samples from Poisson(true_mean)

    • â€exponentialâ€: Samples from Exponential(1.0) shifted to have mean â‰ˆ true_mean

  • delta (tolerated failure probability of binary search in DAME-TS)

Returns:

  • mean_error (float) â€“ The average squared error between the DAME estimate and the true mean over all trials.

  • std_error (float) â€“ The standard deviation of the squared error over all trials.

dame_bs.utils.theoretical_upper_bound(alpha, n, m, delta=0.1)[source]ïƒ

Computes a theoretical upper bound on the mean squared error (MSE) of the algorithmâ€™s estimate of the true mean, under differential privacy constraints.

Parameters:

  • alpha (float) â€“ Differential privacy parameter (Î± > 0).

  • n (int) â€“ Total number of users.

  • m (int) â€“ Number of samples per user.

Returns:

A theoretical upper bound on the expected squared error:

E[(theta_hat - theta)^2], where theta is the true mean and ğœƒtheta_hat is the estimate returned by DAME. The theoretical bound is given by -

E[(theta_hat - theta)^2]<= 32/n +

(16/(Î±^2 n)) max{log((9*np.log(12)/(8*m))),(2/3)**(((2*pi_alpha-1)**2)/(np.log(n/delta_val)))}+ 4 delta

where Ï€_Î± = e^Î± / (1 + e^Î±)

Return type:

float

Module contentsïƒ

DAME-TS: Differentially Private Mean Estimation via Binary Search

dame_bs.attempting_insertion_using_binary_search(alpha, delta, n, m, user_samples)[source]ïƒ

Perform the localization phase of DAME using a private binary search.

This procedure partitions the interval [-1, 1] into three segments at each iteration, uses randomized response to privately count how many user sample-means fall into the left and right thirds, and discards the less-likely segment. It repeats until all groups are exhausted, returning the remaining interval.

Parameters:ïƒ

alphafloat

Differential privacy parameter for the binary (randomized response) queries.

deltafloat

Failure probability tolerated in the localization phase.

nint

Number of users allocated to localization (should be n/2 of the total).

mint

Number of samples per user.

user_sampleslist of array-like

A list of length n, each entry an array-like of m real-valued samples for one user.

Returns:ïƒ

List :

[L,R] = The estimated interval that might contain true mean where L is the lower and R is the upper bound.

dame_bs.run_dame_experiment(n, alpha, m, true_mean, trials=50, distribution='normal', delta=0.1)[source]ïƒ

Runs the DAME-BS algorithm multiple times to empirically evaluate its estimation error under different data distributions and privacy settings.

This function simulates a scenario with n users, each having m samples generated from a specified distribution centered around a known true_mean.

Parameters:

  • n (int) â€“ Total number of users participating in the experiment.

  • alpha (float) â€“ Differential privacy parameter. Higher values allow more accurate estimation with weaker privacy guarantees.

  • m (int) â€“ Number of samples collected per user.

  • true_mean (float) â€“ The actual mean of the underlying data distribution. Used to compute estimation error.

  • trials (int, optional) â€“ Number of times the experiment is repeated (default is 50).

  • distribution (str, optional) â€“

    Type of distribution to sample user data from. Supported values:

    • â€normalâ€ : Samples from N(true_mean, 0.5^2)

    • â€uniformâ€ : Samples from U(true_mean - 1, true_mean + 1)

    • â€poissonâ€ : Samples from Poisson(true_mean)

    • â€exponentialâ€: Samples from Exponential(1.0) shifted to have mean â‰ˆ true_mean

  • delta (tolerated failure probability of binary search in DAME-TS)

Returns:

  • mean_error (float) â€“ The average squared error between the DAME estimate and the true mean over all trials.

  • std_error (float) â€“ The standard deviation of the squared error over all trials.
